div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Sun, [19--]
div1.p:
Dr. H. A. Kelly Speaks Of Discoverer
Of Cause Of Yellow Fever.

Dr. Howard A. Kelly believes that Con-
gress should provide a liberal pension for
the widow of Dr. Walter Reed, who dis-
covered the cause of yellow fever. Dr.
Kelly said yesterday to a reporter of THE
SUN:

"As human nature is constituted there
should always exist a certain reciprocal re-
lation between those, on the one hand, who
confer distinguished favors, and those who,
as the recipients of such favors, have the
opportunity of giving adequate expression
to their gratitude and appreciation. It is
one of the sad records of history, however,
that the men who have conferred the great-
est benefits upon their race have, in many
instances, notably failed to receive their
meed of appreciation from their benefici-
aries. I think no one will quarrel with me
when I insist that if the beneficiary is a
person of wealth and unlimited resources,
while the benefactor is poor, it becomes a
matter of sad reflection on the character of
the recipient should he leave the benefac-
tor who has saved his life in actual want.

"I have made these reflections with the
case of the late Dr. Walter Reed, distin-
guished surgeon of the United States Army
in mind. Dr. Reed solved the problem which
has vexed generations of physicians at home
and abroad; he discovered the cause of the
terrible plague, yellow fever, which has de-
vastated our country for generations, and
simultaneously with the discovery of the
cause he also demonstrated efficient means
of prevention, so that this scourge of an-
cient times is forever conquered and need
never revisit our country claiming its thou-
sands and tens of thousands of victims, as
in the decades past. Traditions still exist,
handed from mouth to mouth, of the awful
epidemic in Philadelphia little over a cen-
tury ago, and I have heard many times in
my own family of the men who drove up
and down the deserted streets with carts,
crying out: ‘Bring out your dead, bring
out your dead!’

"From all this has Dr. Walter Reed saved
our country. He has given us millions of
lives in the generations to come and count-
less millions of money. And now that an
early death has snatched him away how
can we show some slight expression of our
gratitude for the services he has rendered
us? What can the nation do to honor such
a man and to encourage others to spend
their lives in humane research? Surely the
most fitting tribute we can pay such a mem-
ory is to show our appreciation of the com-
fort of her who was his closest companion,
his wife. The least the nation can do is to
devote a modicum of the enormous wealth
he has spared us to her whom he would
have loved most to honor had he lived.

“It is the earnest hope of the medical pro-
fession throughout the country that in ar-
ranging a pension for Mrs. Walter Reed our
representatives at Washington will show a
clear appreciation as to the value of her
husband's services by conferring an amount
in some degree commensurate with the in-
estimable benefits the nation has received
at his hands.”
